div1.p: MISS in her TEENS: OR, THE MEDLEY of LOVERS.
As it is Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Covent-Garden.
LONDON: Printed for J. and R. TONSON in the Strand. M.DCC.XLVII.

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.l: TOO long has Farce, neglecting Nature's Laws,
Debas'd the Stage, and wrong'd the Comic Cause:
To raise a Laugh has been her sole Pretence,
Tho' dearly purchas'd at the Price of Sense;
This Child of Folly gain'd Increase with Time;
Fit for the Place, succeeded Pantomime;
Reviv'd her Honours, join'd her motley Band,
And Song, and low Conceit, o'er-ran the Land.
More gen'rous Views inform our Author's Breast,
From real Life his Characters are drest;
He seeks to trace the Passions of Mankind,
And while he spares the Person, paints the Mind.
In pleasing Contrast he attempts to show
The vap'ring Bully, and the frib'ling Beau,
Cowards alike, That full of Martial Airs,
And This as tender as the Silk he wears.
Proud to divert, not anxious for Renown,
Oft has the Bard essay'd to please the Town,
Your full Applause out-paid his little Art,
He boasts no Merit, but a grateful Heart;
Pronounce your Doom, he'll patiently submit,
Ye sovereign Judges of all Works of Wit!
To you the Ore is brought, a lifeless Mass,
You give the Stamp, and then the Coin may pass.
Now whether Judgment prompt you to forgive,
Whether you bid this trifling Offspring live,
Or with a Frown should send the sickly Thing,
To sleep whole Ages under Dulness' Wing;
To your known Candour we will always trust,
You never were, nor can you be unjust.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: THIS is the Place we were directed to; and now, Puff, if I can get no Intelligence of her, what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: And me too, Sir.—You must consider I am a marry'd Man, and can't bear Fatigue as I have done.—But pray, Sir, why did you leave the Army so abruptly, and not give me Time to fill my Knapsack with common Necessaries? Half a Dozen Shirts, and your Regimentals, are my whole Cargo.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I was wild to get away, and as soon as I obtain'd my Leave of Absence, I thought every Moment an Age till I return'd to the Place where I first saw this young-charming, innocent, bewitching Creature—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: With fifteen thousand Pounds for her Fortune—Strong Motives, I must confess.—And now, Sir, as you are pleas'd to say you must depend upon my Care and Abilities in this Affair, I think I have a just Right to be acquainted with the Particulars of your Passion, that I may be the better enabled to serve you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You shall have 'em.—When I left the University, which is now seven Months since, my Father, who loves his Money better than his Son, and would not settle a Farthing upon me—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Mine did so by me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Purchas'd me a Pair of Colours at my own Request; but before I join'd the Regiment, which was going
abroad, I took a Ramble into the Country with a Fellow-Collegian, to see a Relation of his who liv'd in Berkshire.—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: —A Party of Pleasure, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: During a short Stay there, I came acquainted with this young Creature; she was just come from the Boarding-School, and tho' she had all the Simplicity of her Age and the Country, yet it was mix'd with such sensible Vivacity, that I took Fire at once—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I was Tinder myself at your Age. But pray, Sir, did you take Fire before you knew of her Fortune?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Before, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Folly and Constitution—But on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I was introduced to the Family by the Name of Rhodophil, (for so my Companion and I had settled it;) at the End of three Weeks I was oblig'd to attend the Call of Honour in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Your Parting, to be sure, was Heart-breaking.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I feel it at this Instant.—We vow'd eternal Constancy, and I promis'd to take the first Opportunity of returning to her: I did so, but we found the House shut up, and all the Information, you know, that we could get from the neighbouring Cottage was, that Miss and her Aunt were remov'd to Town, and liv'd somewhere near this Part of it.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: And now we are got to the Place of Action, propose your Plan of Operation.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Father lives but in the next Street, so I must decamp immediately for fear of Discoveries; you are not known to be my Servant, so make what Enquiries you can in the Neighbourhood, and I shall wait at the Inn for your Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I'll patrol hercabouts, and examine all that pass; but I've forgot the Word, Sir—Miss Biddy—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bellair—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: A young Lady of Wit, Beauty, and Fifteen thousand Pounds Fortune—but, Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What do you say, Puff?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: If your Honour pleases to consider that I had a Wife in Town whom I left somewhat abruptly half a Year ago, you'll think it, I believe, but decent, to make some Enquiry after her first; to be sure it would be some small Consolation to me to know whether the poor Woman is living, or has made away with herself, or—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pr'ythec don't distract me; a Moment's Delay is of the utmost Consequence; I must insist upon an immediate Compliance with my Commands.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: The Devil's in these fiery young Fellows! they think of no body's Wants but their own. He does not consider that I am Flesh and Blood as well as himself. However I may kill two Birds at once; for I shan't be surpriz'd if I meet my Lady walking the Streets—But who have we here? Sure I should know that Face.
Who's that? my old Acquaintance, Jasper!

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: What, Puff! are you here?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: My dear Friend! [Kisses him.] Well, and how Jasper, still easy and happy! Toujours le meme!—What Intrigues now? What Girls have you ruin'd, and what Cuckolds made, since you and I us'd to beat up together, Eh?

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Faith, Business has been very brisk during the War; Men are scarce, you know; not that I can say I ever wanted Amusement in the worst of Times.—But harkye. Puff—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Not a Word aloud, I am incognito.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Why Faith, I should not have known you, if you had not spoke first; you seem to be a little dishabille too, as well as incognito. Whom do you honour with your Service now? Are you from the Wars?

sp.speaker: Puff.
Jasper.
sp.p: I don't absolutely live, but I am most of my Time there; I have within these two Months enter'd into the Service of an old Gentleman, who hired a reputable Servant, and dress'd him as you see, because he has taken it into his Head to fall in Love.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: False Appetite and second Childhood! But pr'ythee, what's the Object of his Passion?

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: No less than a Virgin of Sixteen, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Oh, the toothless old Dotard!

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: And he mumbles and plays with her till his Mouth waters; then he chuckles till he cries, and calls it his Bid, and his Bidsy, and is so foolishly fond—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Bidsy! What's that?—

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: —Her Name is Biddy.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Biddy! What, Miss Biddy Bellair?

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: —The same—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I have no Luck, to be sure. [Aside.]—Oh! I have heard of her; she's of a pretty good Family, and has some Fortune, I know. But are things settled? Is the Marriage fixed?

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Not absolutely; the Girl, I believe, detests him; but her Aunt, a very good prudent old Lady, has given her Consent, if he can gain her Niece's; how it will end I can't tell—but I am hot upon't myself.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: —The Devil! not Marriage, I hope.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: That is not yet determined.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Who is the Lady, pray?

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: A Maid in the same Family, a Woman of Honour, I assure you; She has one Husband already, a scoundrel sort of a Fellow that has run away from her, and listed for a Soldier; so, towards the End of the Campaign, she hopes to have a Certificate he's knock'd o' th' Head; if not, I suppose, we shall settle Matters another way.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p:
Well, speed the Plough.—But harkye, consummate
without the Certificate if you can—keep your Neck out of the Collar—do—I have wore it these two Years, and damnably gall'd I am.—

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: I'll take your Advice; but I must run away to my Master, who will be impatient for an Answer to his Message which I have just deliver'd to the young Lady; so, dear Mr. Puff, I am your most obedient humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: And I must to our Agent's for my Arrears: If you have an Hour to spare, you'll hear of me at George's or the Tilt-Yard—Au Revoir, as we say abroad. [Exit Jasper.] Thus we are as civil and as false as our Betters; Jasper and I were always the Beau Monde exactly; we ever hated one another heartily, yet always kiss, and shake Hands—But now to my Master, with a Head full of News, and a Heart full of Joy!
sp.l: Angels, and Ministers of Grace, defend me!
sp.p: It can't be! by Heavens, it is, that fretful Porcupine, my Wife! I can't stand it; what shall I do? I'll try to avoid her.

sp.speaker: Tag.
Puff.
sp.p: I sweat—I tremble—She comes upon me!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Pray, good Sir, If I may be so bold—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I have nothing for you, good Woman, don't trouble me.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: If your Honour pleases to look this way—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: The Kingdom is over-run with Beggars; I suppose the last I gave to has sent this: but I have no more loose Silver about me; so pr'ythee, Woman, don't disturb me.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I can hold no longer; oh you Villain, you! Where have you been, Scoundrel! Do you know me now Varlet?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Here Watch, Watch,—Zounds I shall have my Pockets pick'd.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Own me this Minute, Hang-dog, and confess every thing, or by the Rage of an injur'd Woman, I'll raise the Neighbourhood, throttle you, and send you to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Amazement! what, my own dear Tag! Come to my Arms, and let me press you to my Heart, that pants for thee, and only thee, my true and lawful Wife.—Now my Stars have over-paid me for the Fatigue and Dangers of the Field; I have wander'd about like Achilles in search of faithful Penelope, and the Gods have brought me to this happy Spot.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: The Fellow's crack'd for certain! Leave your bombastick Stuff, and tell me, Rascal, why you left me, and where you have been these six Months, heh?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: We'll reserve my Adventures for our happy Winter Evenings—I shall only tell you now, that my Heart beats so strong in my Country's Cause, and being instigated either by Honour or the Devil, (I cannot tell which) I set out for Flanders, to gather Lawrels, and lay 'em at thy Feet.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: You left me to starve, Villain, and beg my Bread, you did so.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I left you too hastily I must confess, and often has my Conscience flung me for it.—I am got into an Officer's Service, have been in several Actions, gain'd some Credit by my Behaviour, and am now return'd with my Master, to indulge the gender Passions.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Don't think to fob me off with this nonsensical Talk; what have you brought me home besides?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Honour, and immoderate Love.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I could tear your Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Temperance, or I walk off.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Temperance, Traitor, Temperance! What can you say for yourself? Leave me to the wide World.—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Well, I have been in the wide World too, han't I? What would the Woman have?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Reduce me to the Necessity of going to Service.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Why, I'm in Service too, your Lord and Master, an't I, you saucy Jade, you?—Come, where dost live, hereabouts? Hast got good Vails? Dost go to Market? Come, give me a Kiss, Darling, and tell me where I shall pay my Duty to thee.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Why, there I live at that House.
sp.stage: [Pointing to the House Jasper come out of.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: What, there! that House?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Yes, there, that House.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Huzza! We're made for ever, you Slut, you! huzza! Every thing conspires this Day to make me happy—Prepare for an Inundation of Joy! My Master is in love with your Miss Biddy over Head and Ears, and she with him: I know she is courted by some old Fumbler, and her Aunt is not against the Match; but now we are come the Town will be reliev'd, and the Governor brought over; in plain English, our Fortune is made; my Master must marry the Lady, and the old Gentleman may go to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Heyday! what is all this?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Say no more, the Dice are thrown, Doublets for us; away to your young Mistress, while I run to my Master, tell her Rhodophil! Rhodophil! will be with her immediately; then if her Blood does not mount to her Face like Quicksilver in a Weather-glass, and point to extreme hot, believe the whole a Lye, and your Husband no Politician.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: This is news, indeed! I have had the Place but a little while, and have not quite got into the Secrets of the Family; but Part of your Story is true, and if you'll bring your Master, and Miss is willing, I warrant we'll be too hard for the old Folks.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I'll about it straight;—but hold, Tag, I had forgot—Pray how does Mr. Jasper do?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Mr. Jasper!—What do you mean? I—I—I—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p:
What, out of Countenance, Child? Oh fy! Speak
plain, my Dear.—And the Certificate, when comes that, heh, Love?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: He has sold himself and turn'd Conjurer, or he could never have known it.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Are not you a Jade?—Are not you a Jezebel?—Arn't you a—

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: O ho, Temperance! or I walk off—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I know I am not finish'd yet, and so I am easy; but more Thanks to my Fortune than your Virtue, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: [within.] Tag, Tag, where are you, Tag?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Coming, Madam.—My old Lady calls; away, to your Master, and I'll prepare his Reception within.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Shall I bring the Certificate with me?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Go, you graceless Rogue, you richly deserve it.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Who was that Man you were talking to, Tag?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: A Cousin of mine, Madam, that brought me some News from my Aunt in the Country.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Where's my Neice? Why are not you with her?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: She bid me leave her alone—She's so melancholy, Madam, I don't know what's come to her of late—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: The Thoughtfulness that is natural upon the Approach of Matrimony, generally occasions a decent Concern.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: And do you think, Madam, a Husband of threescore and five—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Hold, Tag, he protests to me he is but five and Fifty.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: He is a Rogue, Madam, and an old Rogue, and a fumbling old Rogue, which is the worst of Rogues.—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Alas! Youth or Age, 'tis all one to her; she is all Simplicity without Experience: I would not force her Inclinations, but she's so innocent she won't know the Difference—

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Innocent! ne'er trust to that, Madam; I was innocent myself once, but Live and Learn is an old Saying, and a true one:—I believe, Madam, no Body is more innocent than yourself, and a good Maid you are to be sure but tho' you really don't know the Difference, yet you can fancy it I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: I should prefer a large Jointure to a small one, and that's all; but 'tis impossible that Biddy should have Desires, she's but newly come out of the Country, and just turn'd of Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: That's a ticklish Age, Madam! I have observ'd she does not eat, nor she does not sleep; she sighs, and she cries, and she loves Moon-light; these, I take it, are very strong Symptoms.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
Tag.
sp.p: She'll make him a Cuckold tho' for all that, if you force her to marry him.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
Tag.
sp.p: Chastity! Never trust to that, Madam; get her a Husband that's fit for her, and I'll be bound for her Virtue; but with such a one as Sir Simon, I'm a Rogue if I'd answer for my own.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Well, Tag, the Child shall never have reason to repent of my Severity; I was going before to my Lawyers to speak about the Articles of Marriage. I will now put a Stop to 'em for some time, till we can make farther Discoveries.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Heav'n will bless you for your Goodness; look where the poor Bird comes, quite mop'd and melancholy; I'll set my Pump at work, and draw something from her before your Return, I warrant you.
There goes a Miracle; she has neither Pride, Envy, or Ill-nature, and yet is near Sixty, and a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: How unfortunate a poor girl am I, I dare not tell my Secrets to any Body, and if I don't I'm undone—Heigho! [Sighs.] Pray, Tag, is my Aunt gone to her Lawyer about me? Heigho!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: What's that Sigh for my dear young Mistress?

sp.speaker: Bid.
sp.p: I did not sigh, not I— [Sighs.]

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Nay, never gulp 'em down, they are the worst Things you can swallow. There's something in that little Heart of yours, that swells it and puffs it, and will burst it at last, if you don't give it vent.

sp.speaker: Bid.
sp.p: What would you have me tell you?[Sighs.]

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Come, come, your are afraid I'll betray you, but you had as good speak, I may do you some Service you little think of.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: It is not in your Power, Tag, to give me what I want.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Not directly, perhaps; but I may be the means of helping you to it; as for Example—If you should not like to marry the old Man your Aunt designs for you, one might find a way to break—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: His Neck, Tag?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Or the Match; either will do, Child.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I don't care which indeed, so I was clear of him—I don't think I'm fit to be marry'd.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: To him you mean—You have no Objection to Marriage, but the Man, and I applaud you for it: But come, Courage, Miss, never keep it in; out with it all—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: If you'll ask me any Questions, I'll answer 'em, but I can't tell you any thing of myself, I shall blush if I do.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Well then—In the first Place, Pray tell me, Miss Biddy Bellair, if you don't like somebody better than old Sir Simon Loveit?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: What's Heigho, Miss?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: When I say Heigho! it means yes.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Very well; and this Somebody is a young handsome Fellow?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: And if you were once his, you'd be as merry as the best of us?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: So far so good: and since I have got you to wet your Feet, souce over Head at once, and the Pain will be over.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: There—then. [A long Sigh.] Now help me out, Tag, as fast as you can.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: When did you hear from your Gallant?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Never since he went to the Army.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I was afraid the Letters would fall into my Aunt's Hands, so I would not let him write to me; but I had a better Reason then.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Pray let's hear that too.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Why, I thought if I should write to him, and promise him to love no body else, and should afterwards change my Mind, he might think I was inconstant, and call me a Coquette.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: What a simple Innocent it is! [Aside.] And have you chang'd your Mind, Miss?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: No indeed, Tag, I love him the best of any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Of any of 'em! Why, have you any more?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Pray don't ask me.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Nay, Miss, if you only trust me by Halves, you can't expect—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I will trust you with every thing.—When I parted with him, I grew melancholy; so in order to divert me, I have let two others court me till he returns again.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Is that all, my Dear? Mighty simple, indeed.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: One of 'em is a fine blustering Man, and is call'd Captain Flash; he's always talking of Fighting, and Wars; he thinks he's sure of me, but I shall balk him; we shall see him this Afternoon, for he press'd strongly to come, and I have given him Leave, while my Aunt's taking her Afternoon's Nap.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: And who is the other, pray?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Quite another sort of a Man; he speaks like a Lady for all the World, and never swears as Mr. Flash does, but wears nice white Gloves, and tells me what Ribbons become my Complexion, where to stick my Patches, who is the best Millener, where they sell the best Tea, and which is the best Wash for the Face, and the best Paste for the Hands; he is always playing with my Fan, and shewing his Teeth, and whenever I speak he pats me—so—and cries, The Devil take me, Miss Biddy, but you'll be my Perdition—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Oh the pretty Creature! And what do you call him pray?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: His Name's Fribble; you shall see him too, for by Mistake I appointed 'em at the same time; but you must help me out with 'em.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: And suppose your Favourite should come too—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I should not care what became of the others.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: What's his Name?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: It begins with an R—h—o—

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if it is not Rhodophil.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I am frighten'd at you! You are a Witch, Tag!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I am so, and I can tell your Fortune too. Look me in the Face. The Gentleman you love most in the World will be at our House this Afternoon; he arriv'd from the Army this Morning, and dies till he sees you.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Is he come, Tag? Don't joke with me—

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Not to keep you longer in Suspence, you must know the Servant of your Strephon, by some unaccountable Fate or other, is my Lord and Master; he has just been with me, and told me of his Master's Arrival and Impatience—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Oh my dear, dear Tag, you have put me out of my Wits—I am all over in a Flutter—I shall leap out of my Skin—I don't know what to do with myself—Is he come, Tag?—I am ready to faint—I'd give the World I had put on my Pink and Silver Robings to-day.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I assure you, Miss, you look charmingly!

sp.speaker: Biddy,
sp.p: Do I indeed tho'? I'll put a little Patch under my left Eye, and powder my Hair immediately.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: We'll go to Dinner first, and then I'll assist you.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Dinner! I can't eat a Morsel—I don't know what's the Matter with me—my Ears tingle, my Heart beats, my Face flushes, and I tremble every Joint of me—I must run in and look myself in the Glass this Moment.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Yes, she has it, and deeply too; this is no Hypocrisy—
sp.l: Not Art, but Nature now performs her Part,
And every Word's the Language of the Heart.

div2.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div2.stage: Enter Captain Loveit, Biddy, Tag, and Puff.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: TO find you still constant, and to arrive at such a critical Juncture, is the height of Fortune and Happiness

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Nothing shall force me from you; and if I am secure of your Affections—

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I'll be bound for him, Madam, and give you any Security you can ask.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Every thing goes on to our Wish, Sir; I just now had a second Conference with my old Lady, and she was so convinced by my Arguments, that she return'd instantly to the Lawyer to forbid the drawing out of any Writings at all, and she is determin'd never to thwart Miss's Inclinations, and left it to us to give the old Gentleman his Discharge at the next Visit.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Shall I undertake the old Dragon?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: If we have Occasion for Help, we shall call for you.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I expect him every Moment, therefore I'll tell you what, Rhodophil, you and your Man shall be lock'd up in my Bed-chamber till we have settled Matters with the old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do what you please with me.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: You must not be impatient tho'

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I can undergo any thing with such a Reward in view, one Kiss and I'll be quite resign'd—and now shew me the way.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Come. Sirrah, when I have got you under Lock and Key, I shall bring you to Reason.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Are your Wedding-clothes ready, my Dove? the Certificate's come.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Go follow your Captain, Sirrah—march—You may Thank Heav'n I had Patience to stay so long.

sp.speaker: Biddy,
sp.p: I was very much alarm'd for fear my two Gallants should come in upon us unawares; we should have had sad work if they had: I find I love Rhodophil vastly, for tho' my other Sparks flatter me more, I can't abide the thoughts of 'em now—I have Business upon my Hands enough to turn my little Head, but egad my Heart's good, and a Fig for Dangers—let me see, what shall I do with my two Gallants? I must, at least, part with 'em decently; suppose I set 'em together by the Ears?—The luckiest thought in the World! For if if they won't quarrel (as I believe they won't) I can break with them for Cowards, and very justly dismiss 'em my Service; and if they will fight, and one of 'em should be kill'd, the other will certainly be hang'd, or run away, and so I shall very handsomely get rid of both.—I am glad I have settled it so purely.
Well, Tag, are they safe?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I think so, the Door's double lock'd, and I have the Key in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: That's pure; but have you given 'em any thing to divert 'em?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I have given the Captain one of your old Gloves to mumble, but my Strephon is diverting himself with the more substantial Comforts of a cold Ven'son Pasty.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: What shall we do with the next that comes?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p:
If Mr. Fribble comes first, I'll clap him up into my Lady's Store-room; I suppose he is a great Maker
of Marmalade himself, and will have an Opportunity of making some critical Remarks upon our Pastry and Sweet-meats.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: When one of 'em comes, do you go and watch for the other, and as soon as you see him, run in to us, and pretend it is my Aunt, and so we shall have an Excuse to lock him up till we want him.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: You may depend upon me; here is one of 'em.—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Mr. Fribble, your Servant—

sp.speaker: Fribble.
sp.p: Miss Biddy your Slave—I hope I have not come upon you abruptly; I should have waited upon you sooner, but an Accident happen'd that discompos'd me so, that I was obliged to go home again to take Drops.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Indeed you don't look well, Sir.—Go, Tag, and do as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I have set my Maid to watch my Aunt, that we mayn't be surprized by her.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Your Prudence is equal to your Beauty, Miss, and I hope your permitting me to kiss your Hands, will be no Impeachment of your Understanding.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I hate the Sight of him. [Aside.] I was afraid I should not have had the Pleasure of seeing you, pray let me know what Accident you met with, and what's the matter with your Hand? I shan't be easy till I know.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p:
Well I vow, Miss Biddy, you're a good Creater,—I'll endeavour to muster up what little Spirits I have, and tell you the whole Affair—Hem!—But first you must give me leave to make you a Present of a small Pot of my Lip-salve; My Servant made it this Morning—the Ingredients are innocent, I assure
you; nothing but the best Virgin's-wax, Conserve of Roses, and Lilly of the Valley Water.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, but my Lips are generally red, and, when they an't, I bite 'em.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I bite my own, sometimes, to pout 'em a little, but this will give them a Softness, Colour, and an agreeable Moister.—Thus let me make an humble Offering at that Shrine, where I have already sacrific'd my Heart.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Upon my Word that is very prettily express'd, you are positively the best Company in the World—I wish he was out of the House.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: But to return to my Accident, and the Reason why my Hand is in this Condition—I beg you'll excuse the Appearance of it, and be satisfyed that nothing but mere Necessity could have forc'd me to appear thus muffled before you.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I am very willing to excuse any Misfortune that happens to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p:
You are vastly good indeed,—thus it was.—Hem!—You must know, Miss, there is not an Animal in the Creation I have so great an Aversion to, as those Hackney-coach Fellows—As I was coming out of my Lodgings,—Says one of 'em to me, Would your Honour heve a Coach?—No, Man, said I, not now (with all the Civility imaginable)—I'll carry you and your Doll too, (says he) Miss Margery for the same Price.—Upon which the masculine Beasts about us fell a laughing; then I turn'd round in a great Passion, curse me, (says I) Fellow, but I'll trounce thee.—And, as I was holding out my Hand in a threatning Poster,—thus;—he makes a Cut at me with his Whip, and striking me over the Nail of my little Finger, it gave me such exquisite Torter that I fainted away; and, while I was in this Condition, the
Mob pick'd my Pocket of my Purse, my Scissars, my Mocoa Smelling-Bottle, and my Huswife.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I shall laugh in his Face. (Aside.) I am afraid you are in great Pain; pray sit down, Mr. Fribble, but I hope your Hand is in no Danger.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Not in the least, Maam; pray don't be apprehensive—A Milk-poultice, and a gentle Sweat to Night, with a little Manna in the Morning, I am confident will relieve me entirely.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: But pray, Mr. Fribble, do you make use of a Huswife?

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I can't do without it, Maam; there is a Club of us, all young Batchelors, the sweetest Society in the World; and we meet three times a Week at each others Lodgings, where we drink Tea, hear the Chat of the Day, invent Fashions for the Ladies, make Models of 'em, and cut out Patterns in Paper. We were the first Inventors of Knotting, and this Fringe is the original Produce and joint Labour of our little Community.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: And who are your pretty Set, pray?

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: There's Phil Whiffle, Jacky Wagtail, my Lord Trip, Billy Dimple, Sir Dilbery Diddle, and your humble—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: What a sweet Collection of happy Creatures!

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Indeed and so we are, Miss,—But a prodigious Fracas disconcerted us some time ago at Billy Dimple's—three drunken naughty Women of the Town burst into our Club-room, curst us all, threw down the China, broke six Looking-glasses, scalded us with the Slop-Bason, and scrat poor Phil Whiffle's Cheek in such a manner, that he has kept his Bed these three Weeks.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p:
Indeed, Mr. Fribble, I think all our Sex have great Reason to be angry; for if you are so happy now
you are Batchelors, the Ladies may wish and sigh to very little purpose.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: You are mistaken, I assure you; I am prodigiously rallied about my Passion for you, I can tell you that, and am look'd upon as lost to our Society already; He, he, he!

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Fribble, now you have gone so far, don't think me impudent if I long to know how you intend to use the Lady who shall be honour'd with your Affections?

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Not as most other Wives are us'd, I assure you; all the domestick Business will be taken off her Hands; I shall make the Tea, comb the Dogs, and dress the Children myself, so that tho' I'm a Commoner, Mrs. Fribble will lead the Life of a Woman of Quality; for she will have nothing to do, but lie in Bed, play at Cards, and scold the Servants.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: What a happy Creature must she be!

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Do you really think so? Then pray let me have a little serous Talk with you.—Tho' my Passion is not of a long standing, I hope the Sincerity of my Intentions—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Go, you wild Thing. [Pats her.] The Devil take me but there is no talking to you.—How can you use me in this barbarous manner! If I had the Constitution of an Alderman it would sink under my Sufferings—hooman Nater can't support it.—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Why, what would you do with me, Mr. Fribble?

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Well, I vow I'll beat you if you talk so—don't look at me in that manner.—Flesh and Blood can't bear it—I could—but I won't grow indecent—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p:
But pray, Sir, where are the Verses you were to write upon me? I find if a young Lady depends too
much upon such fine Gentlemen as you, she'll certainly be disappointed.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I vow, the Flutter I was put into this Afternoon has quite turn'd my Senses—here they are tho'—and I believe you'll like 'em.—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: There can be no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I protest, Miss, I dont like that Curtsey—Look at me, aud always rise in this manner. [Shews her] But, my dear Creater, who put on your Cap to-day? They have made a Fright of you, and it's as yellow as old Lady Crowfoot's Neck.—When we are settled, I'll dress your Heads myself.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Pray read the Verses to me, Mr. Fribble.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I obey—Hem!—William Fribble, Esq to Miss Biddy Bellair—greeting.
sp.l: No Ice so hard, so cold as I,
'Till warm'd and softn'd by your Eye;
And now my Heart dissolves away
In Dreams by Night, in Sighs by Day;
No brutal Passion fires my Breast,
Which loaths the Object when possess'd;
But one of harmless, gentle Kind,
Whose Joys are center'd—in the Mind:
Then take with me Love's better Port,
His downy Wing, but not his Dart.
sp.p: How do you like them?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I swear they are very pretty—but I don't quite understand 'em.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: These light Pieces are never so well understood in Reading as Singing; I have set 'em myself, and will endeavour to give 'em you—La la—I have an abominable Cold, and can't sing a Note; however the Tune's nothing, the Manner's all.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Your Aunt, your Aunt, your Aunt, Madam!

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Hide, hide Mr. Fribble, Tag, or we are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Oh! for Heaven's sake put me any where, so I don't dirty my Clothes.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Put him into the Store-room, Tag, this Moment.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Is it a damp Place, Mrs. Tag? The Floor is boarded, I hope?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Indeed it is not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: What shall I do? I shall certainly catch my Death! Where's my Cambrick Handkerchief, and my Salts? I shall certainly have my Hystericks!

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: In, in, in—So now let the other come as soon as he will; I did not care if I had twenty of 'em, so they would but come one after another.
Was my Aunt coming?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: No, 'twas Mr. Flash, I suppose, by the Length of his Stride, and the Cock of his Hat. He'll be here this Minute—What shall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I'll manage him, I warrant you, and try his Courage; be sure you are ready to second me—we shall have pure Sport.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Hush! here he comes.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p:
Well my Blossom, here am I! What Hopes for a poor Dog, eh? How! the Maid here! then I've lost the Town, Dammee! Not a Shilling to
bribe the Governor; she'll spring a Mine, and I shall be blown to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Don't be asham'd, Mr. Flash; I have told Tag the whole Affair, and she's my Friend I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Is she? Then she wont be mine I am certain [Aside.] Well Mrs. Tag, you know, I suppose, what's to be done: This young Lady and I have contracted our-selves, and so, if you please to stand Bridemaid, why we'll fix the Wedding-day directly.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: The Wedding-day, Sir?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: The Wedding-day, Sir? Ay, Sir, the Wedding-day, Sir, what have you to say to that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: My dear Captain Flash, don't make such a Noise, you'll 'wake my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: And suppose I did, Child, what then?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: She'd be frighten'd out of her Wits.

sp.speaker: Flash.
Tag.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you flatter yourself—But pray, Sir, what are your Pretensions?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: The Lady's Promises, my own Passion, and the best mounted Blade in the three Kingdoms. If any Man can produce a better Title, let him take her; if not, the D—l mince me, if I give up an Atom of her.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: He's in a fine Passion, if he would but hold it.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, hear Reason a little.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p:
I never do, Madam; it is not my Method of Proceeding; here's my Logick; [Draws his Sword.] Sa, sa,—my best Argument is Cart over Arm, Madam, ha, ha, [lunges.] and if he answers that, Madam,
through my small Guts, my Breath. Blood and Mistress are all at his Service—Nothing more, Madam.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: This 'll do, this 'll do.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: But Sir, Sir, Sir?

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: But Madam, Madam, Madam: I profess Blood, Madam, I was bred up to it from a Child; I study the Book of Fate, and the Camp is my my University; I have attended the Lectures of Prince Charles upon the Rhine, and Bathiani upon the Po, and have extracted Knowledge from the Mouth of a Cannon; I'm not to be frighten'd with Squibs, Madam, no, no.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Pray, dear Sir, don't mind her, but let me prevail with you to go away this Time—Your Passion is very fine to be sure, and when my Aunt and Tag are out of the way, I'll let you know when I'd have you come again.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: When you'd have me come again, Child? And suppose I never would come again, what do you think of that now, ha? You pretend to be afraid of your Aunt; your Aunt knows what's what too well to refuse a good Match when 'tis offer'd—Lookee, Miss, I'm a Man of Honour, Glory's my Aim, I have told you the Road I am in, and do you see here, Child, [Shewing his Sword.] no Tricks upon Travellers.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, hear me.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: No, no, no, I know the World, Madam, I am as well known at Covent-Garden as the Dial, Madam: I'll break a Lamp, bully a Constable, bam a Justice, or bilk a Box-keeper with any in the Liberties of Westminster; What do you think of me now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Pray don't be so surious, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flash
sp.p: Come, come, come, few Words are best, somebody's happier than somebody, and I'm a poor silly Fellow; ha, ha,—That's all—Look you Child, to be short, (for I'm a Man of Reflexion) I have but a Bagatelle to say to you: I am in love with you up to Hell and Desperation, may the Sky crush me if I am not—But since there is another more fortunate than I, Adieu, Biddy! Prosperity to the happy Rival, Patience to poor Flash; but the first time we meet—Gunpowder be my Perdition, but I'll have the Honour to cut a Throat with him

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: [Stopping him.] You may meet with him now, if you please.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Now may I!—Where is he? I'll sacrifice the Villain.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Hush! he's but in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Is he? Ram me [Low.] into a Mortar-piece, but I'll have Vengeance; my blood boils to be at him—Don't be frighten'd, Miss!

sp.speaker: Biddy,
sp.p: No, Sir, I never was better pleased, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I shall soon do his Business.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: As soon as you please, take your own Time.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I'll fetch the Gentleman to you immediately.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: [Stopping her.] Stay, stay a little; what a Passion I am in!—Are you sure he is in the next Room?—Ishall certainly tear him to pieces.—I would fain murder him like a Gentleman too—Besides, this Family shan't be brought into Trouble upon my Account.—I have it—I'll watch for him in the Street, and mix his Blood with the Puddle of the next Kennel.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p:
[Stopping him.] No, pray Mr. Flash, let me see
the Battle, I shall be glad to see you fight for me, you shan't go, indeed.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: [Holding him.] Oh, pray let me see you fight; there were two Gentlemen fit Yesterday, and my Mistress was never so diverted in her Life—I'll fetch him out.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Do, stick him, stick him, Captain Flash; I shall love you the better for it.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: D—n your Love, I wish I was out of the House.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Here he is—Now speak some of your hard Words, and run him through—

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Don't be in Fits now—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Never fear me.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: [To Fribble.] Take it on my Word, Sir, he is a Bully, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: [Frighten'd.] I know you are my good Friend, but perhaps you don't know his Disposition.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I am confident he is a Coward.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Is he? Nay, then I'm his Man.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I like his Looks, but I'll not venture too far at first.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Speak to him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I will—I understand, Sir—hem—that you—by Mrs. Tag here,—Sir,—who has inform'd me—hem—that you have sent her, to inform me—Sir,—that you would be glad to speak with me—Demmee—

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: I can speak to you, Sir—or to any Body, Sir—or I can let it alone and hold my Tongue,—if I see Occasion, Sir, Dammee—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Well said, Mr. Flash, be in a Passion.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: [To Fribble.] Don't mind his Looks, he changes Colour already; to him, to him,

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Don't hurry me, Mrs. Tag, for Heaven's sake! I shall be out of breath before I begin if you do—Sir,— [To Flash.] If you can't speak to a Gentleman in another manner, Sir,—why then I'll venture to say, you had better hold your Tongue—Oons.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Sir, you and I are of different Opinions.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: You and your Opinion may go to the Devil—Take that.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Well said, Sir, the Day's your own.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: What's the Matter, Mr. Flash? Is all your Fury gone? Do you give me up?

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I have done his Business.

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: Give you up, Madam! No, Madam; when I am determin'd in my Resolutions I am always clam; 'tis our Way, Madam; and now I shall proceed to Business;—Sir, I beg to say a Word to you in private.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: Keep your Distance, Fellow, and I'll answer you.—That Lady has confess'd a Passion for me, and as she has deliver'd up her Heart into my Keeping, nothing but my 'arts Blood shall purchase it. Demnation!

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Bravo! Bravo!

sp.speaker: Flash.
sp.p: If those are the Conditions, I'll give you Earnest for it directly. [Draws] Now, Villain renounce all Right and Title this Minute, or the Torrent of my Rage will overflow my Reason, and I shall annihilate the Nothingness of your Soul in an Instant.

sp.speaker: Frib.
sp.p: I wish there was a Constable at Hand to take us both up; we shall certainly do one another a Prejudice.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: No, you won't indeed, Sir; Pray bear up to him; if you would but draw your Sword, and be in a Passion, he would run away directly,

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do you hear, Jasper?—Sure the Child is possess'd!—Pray, Miss, what did they want here?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Me, Sir; they wanted me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What did they want with you, I say?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Why, what do you want with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do you hear, Jasper?—I am thunder-struck! I can't believe my own Ears!—Tell me the Reason, I say, why—

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: I'll tell you the Reason why, if you please, Sir Simon. Miss, you know, is a very silly young Girl, and having found out (Heaven knows how!) that there is some little Difference between Sixty-five and twenty-five, she's ridiculous enough to choose the latter; when if she'd take my Advice—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You are right, Tag, she wou'd take me? Eh?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, as the only way to have both; for if she marries you, the other will follow of course.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do you hear, Jasper?

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: 'Tis very true. Sir Simon; from my knowing no better, I have set my Heart upon a young Man, and a young one I'll have; there have been there here this Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Three, Jasper!

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: And they have been quarrelling about me, and one has beat the other two. Now, Sir Simon, if you'll take up the Conqueror, and kick him, as he has kick'd the others, you shall have me for your Reward, and my Fifteen thousand Pounds into the Bargain. What says my Hero? Eh?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: The World's at an End!—What's to be done, Jasper?

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Pack up and be gone; don't fight the Match, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Flesh and Blood cannot bear it—I'm all over Agitation—Hugh, hugh!—am I cheated by a Baby, a
Doll? Where's your Aunt, you young Cockatrice?—I'll let her know—she's a base Woman, and you are—

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: You are in a fine Humour to shew your Valour. Tag, fetch the Captain this Minute, while Sir Simon is warm, and let him know he is waiting here to cut his Throat. [Exit Tag.] I lock'd him up in my Bed-chamber till you came.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Here's an Imp of Darkness! What would I give that my Son Bob was here to thrash her Spark, while I—ravish'd the rest of the Family.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: I believe we had best retire, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, no, I must see her Bully first; and, do you hear, Jasper, if I put him in a Passion, do you knock him down.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Pray keep your Temper, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: [Approaching angrily.] What is the Meaning, Sir?—Ounds! 'tis my Father, Puff; what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: [Drawing him by the Coat.] Kennel again, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am enchanted!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There is no Retreat, I must stand it!

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Captain Fire-ball.—You are welcome from the Wars, noble Captain.—I did not think I should have the Pleasure of being knock'd o' th' Head, or-cut up alive by so fine a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am under such Confusion, Sir, I have not Power to convince you of my Innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Innocence! pretty Lamb! And so, Sir, you have left the Regiment, and the honourable Employment of fighting for your Country, to come home and cut your Father's Throat; why you'll be a great Man in time, Bob!

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: His Father, Tag!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Come, come, 'tis soon done—one Stroke
does it—or, if you have any Qualms, let your 'Squire there perform the Operation.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't throw such Temptations in my way.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hold your impudent Tongue!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Why don't you speak, Mr. Modesty; what Excuse have you for leaving the Army, I say?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Affection to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Your Affection, Puppy!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Our Love, Sir, has been long and mutual; what Accidents have happen'd since my going abroad, and her leaving the Country, and how I have most unaccountably met you here, I am a Stranger to; but whatever Appearances may be, I still am, and ever was, your dutiful Son.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: He talks like an Angel, Tag!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Dutiful, Sirrah! Have you not rival'd your Father?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, Sir, you have rival'd me; my Claim must be prior to yours.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Simon, he can shew the best Title to me.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, the young Gentleman speaks well, and as the Fortune will not go out of the Family, I would advise you to drop your Resentment, be reconcil'd to your Son, and relinquish the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ay, ay, with all my Heart—Look ye, Son, I give you up the Girl, she's too much for me, I confess;—And take my Word, Bob, you'll catch a Tartar.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir Simon, I'm not the Person you take me for; if I have us'd you any ways ill, 'twas for your Son's sake, who had my Promise and Inclinations before you; and tho' I believe I should have made you a most uncomfortable Wife, I'll be the best Daughter to you in the World; and if you stand in need of a Lady, my Aunt is disengag'd, and is the best Nurse—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
No, no, I thank you, Child; you have so turn'd my Stomach to Marriage, I have no Appetite left.—
But where is this Aunt? Won't she stop your Proceedings, think you?

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: She's now at her Lawyer's, Sir, and if you please to go with the young Couple, and give your Approbation, I'll answer for my old Lady's Consent.

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: The Captain, and I, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Come, come, Bob, you are but an Ensign, don't impose on the Girl neither.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I had the good Fortune, Sir, to please my Royal General by my Behaviour in a small Action with the Enemy, and he gave me a Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Bob, I wish you Joy! This is News indeed! And when we celebrate your Wedding, Son, I'll drink a half Pint Bumper myself to your Benefactor.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And he deserves it, Sir; such a General, by his Example and Justice, animates us to Deeds of Glory, and insures us Conquest.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Right, my Boy—come along then.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Halt a little, Gentlemen and Ladies, if you please: Every Body here seems well satisfy'd but myself.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's the Matter, Puff?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Sir, as I would make myself worthy of such a Master, and the Name of Soldier, I cannot put up the least Injury to my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Heyday! What Flourishes are these?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Here is the Man; come forth, Caitiff. [To Jasper.] He hath confess'd this Day, that, in my Absence, he had taken Freedoms with my lawful Wife, and had dishonourable Intentions against my Bed; for which I demand Satisfaction.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: [Striking him.] What Stuff is here, the Fellow's Brain's turn'd.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: And crack'd too, Sir; but you are my Master's Father, and I submit.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Come, come, I'll settle your Punctilios, and will
take care of you and Tag hereafter, provided you drop all Animosities, and shake Hands this Moment.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: My Revenge gives way to my Interest, and I once again, Jasper, take you to my Bosom.

sp.speaker: Jasper.
sp.p: I'm your Friend again, Puff—but harkye—I fear you not; and if you'll lay aside your Steel there, as far as a broken Head, or a black Eye, I'm at your Service upon Demand.

sp.speaker: Tag.
sp.p: You are very good at Crowing indeed, Mr. Jasper; but let me tell you, the Fool that is Rogue enough to brag of a Woman's Favours, must be a Dunghill every way—As for you, my dear Husband, shew your Manhood in a proper Place, and you need not fear these Sheep-biters.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: The Abigail is pleasant I confess, he, he!

sp.speaker: Biddy.
sp.p: I'm afraid the Town will be ill-natur'd enough to think I have been a little coquettish in my Behaviour; but, I hope, as I have been constant to the Captain, I shall be excus'd diverting myself with Pretenders.
sp.l: Ladies, to Fops and Braggarts ne'er be kind,
No Charms can warm 'em, and no Virtues bind;
Each Lover's Merit by his Conduct prove,
Who fails in Honour, will be false in Love.

div1.head: EPILOGUE, by the same Hand as the PROLOGUE.
Spoke by Mrs. PRITCHARD.

lg.l: GOOD Folks, I'm came at my young Lady's bidding,
To say, You all are welcome to her Wedding.
Th'Exchange she made, what Mortal here can blame?
Shew me the Maid that would not do the same.
For sure the greatest Monster ever seen,
Is doting Sixty coupled to Sixteen!
When wint'ry Age had almost caught the Fair,
Youth, clad in Sunshine, snatch'd her from Despair:
Like a new Semele the Virgin lay,
And clasp'd her Lover in the Blaze of Day.
Thus may each Maid, the Toils almost intrapt-in,
Change Old Sir Simon for the brisk young Captain.
I love these Men of Arms, they know their Trade:
Let Dastards sue, these Sons of Fire invade!
They cannot bear around the Bait to nibble,
Like pretty, powder'd, patient Mr. Fribble:
To Dangers bred, and skilful in Command,
They storm the strongest Fortress, Sword in Hand!
Nights without Sleep, and Floods of Tears when waking,
Shew'd poor Miss Biddy was in piteous taking:
She's now quite well; for Maids in that Condition,
Find the young Lover is the best Physician;
And without Helps of Art, or Boast of Knowledge,
They cure more Women, faith, than all the College!
But to the Point—I come with low Petition,
For, faith, poor Bayes is in a sad Condition;
Alluding to Bayes's Prologue in the Rehearsal. The huge tall Hangman stands to give the Blow,
And only waits your Pleasures—Ay, or No.
If you should—Pit, Box, and Gallery, egad!
Joy his Senses, and the Man runs mad:
But if your Ears are shut, your Hearts are Rock,
And you pronounce the Sentence—Block to Block,
Down kneels the Bard, and leaves you when he's dead,
The empty Tribute of an Author's Head.
